cards.title: Men's doubles / Jamie Murray misses out in final to add to family misery
cards.rawTitle: Jamie Murray misses out in final to add to family misery

item.title: Jamie Murray misses out on second Wimbledon doubles crown
item.trailText: Britain’s Jamie Murray and his Australian partner John Peers were beaten 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 by fourth seeds Jean-Julien Rojer and Horia Tecau in the men’s doubles final at Wimbledon
item.standFirst:
• Rojer and Tecau beat Jamie Murray and John Peers 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 in final
• Jamie Murray fails to add men’s doubles title to mixed crown he won in 2007
item.body:
There was a painful sense of deja vu for the Murray family as Jamie suffered a thumping straight-sets defeat in the men’s doubles final on Saturday evening – 24 hours after his brother Andy succumbed to Roger Federer on Centre Court.

Related: Andy Murray must hurry to recover from Wimbledon loss to Roger Federer

Jamie, at 29 the elder Murray brother by a year, won the mixed doubles title with Jelena Jankovic in 2007 and was aiming to become the first Briton since Leslie Godfree in 1926 to claim both the Wimbledon men’s and mixed doubles titles. But it was not to be as Murray and his partner, the Australian John Peers, lost 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 to the No4 seeds, Jean-Julien Rojer and Horia Tecau.

One of Godfree’s other claims to fame was that he played the first match on Centre Court when it opened in 1922. According to legend, his opening serve went into the net so he walked up to his ball and put it in his pocket as a souvenir. After this final Murray’s pockets will also be a little heavier: both he and Peers, the 13th seeds, walked away with £85,000 for being runners-up.

Yet after a positive opening they were second best for much of the match.

Tecau, in particular, played textbook doubles tennis. His serve was impenetrable. His volleys were as sharp as any blade. And his return never stopped asking questions. As Murray admitted: “I felt they got momentum early and that was the difference. If we could have snuck out a break early, things could have gone completely different. But they deserved to win.”

Most of Centre Court was taking a breather after the women’s final when the players arrived on court but the noise that greeted them was passionate and partisan. One wag summed up the mood moments before play started: “Come on Jamie, do it for Scotland!” Seconds later Murray hit a crosscourt winner against Rojer’s serve to go up 0-15 up and the volume went even higher.

And while Rojer and Tecau just about held their opening service game from 15-30, the tone was set for the opening 30 minutes of the match – with Murray and Peers pressing for a break and their opponents doggedly holding them at bay.

They had two breakpoint chances at 1-1 only for Tecau’s muscular serve to dig him out of a hole, and another one at 2-2 when Murray’s vicious dipping return swirled and stung Rojer’s shoelaces. Yet Peers was unable to take advantage, first hitting a return straight at Tecau then sending his lob wide.

Unfortunately while the Australian was serving well, his return game was as streaky as zigzag-cut bacon: he went games without disturbing the wall that Rojer and Tecau put up at the net before suddenly whipping up a couple of passing shots in quick succession before going arctic cold again.

Murray, though, was playing well and dropped only one point on serve and also saved a breakpoint at 4-5 down before the first set went to a tie-break. His brother Andy, who had been unsure whether he would watch for fear of jinxing him, watched on discreetly from three rows above the players’ box, quietly urging him on.

“I didn’t know he was coming until I heard him shouting encouragement,” admitted Jamie to laughs afterwards.

But Rojer and Tecau were gradually finding their feet on their return game and at 3-2 on the tie-break they drew a crucial mistake from Peers at the net. That mini-break proved enough, with Rojer and Tecau clinching the tie-break 7-5 after a final point that was a mini-classic.

Three times Peers and Murray dived to get smashes back before Tecau settled the argument with a thunderbolt bludgeoned down the middle.

The loss of the opening set meant that Murray and Peers had to regroup quickly but they soon went a break down in the second when Peers lost his serve.

At 4-3 on Rojer’s serve, there was a glimmer of hope at 15-30 but it was soon strangled as Rojer saved the game and, shortly afterwards, a flying Tecau smash put them two sets up.

Murray and Peers had twice won five-setters during this Wimbledon but never looked like knocking their opponents off their stride. And at 4-4 in the third Peers tossed in a double fault at 30-30, allowing Rojer and Tecau to pounce. A game later it was all over.

With this victory Tecau became the first Romanian player to win a Wimbledon men’s doubles title since Ilie Nastase in 1973 with Jimmy Connors. And that he finally triumphed after losing in his three previous finals here in 2010, 2011 and 2012 might give encouragement to Murray. Not that he was feeling it last night.

“I guess it’s a missed opportunity,” he sighed. “We may never have a chance to play a grand slam final again.”

displayImages.altText: Andy Murray shouts encouragement to his brother Jamie in the men’s doubles final at Wimbledon.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

cards.title: Williams takes more SW19 records as calendar grand slam beckons
cards.rawTitle: Williams takes more SW19 records as calendar grand slam beckons

item.title: Serena Williams heads for calendar grand slam beyond Wimbledon records
item.trailText: Serena Williams moved one behind Steffi Graf on the major winners’ leaderboard and, due to her current dominance, stands every chance of completing the calendar grand slam at the US Open
item.standFirst: With victory over Garbiñe Muguruza in the women’s final, the world No1 moved one behind Steffi Graf on the major winners’ leaderboard and is still going strong
item.body:
The superlatives are running out as the milestones whiz past and history blurs. Serena Williams captured her sixth Wimbledon singles title and 21st major championship on a flawless Saturday afternoon with a 6-4, 6-4 win over Garbiñe Muguruza. Surely now recognition as the greatest ever women’s tennis player is no longer a point of dispute but a jumping-off point for her broader influence across society at large.

Related: Serena Williams beats battling Garbiñe Muguruza to win Wimbledon

A black female Jehovah’s Witness from Compton continues to rewrite the record books of a sport once the province of the wealthy and privileged, winning with unspeakable power and grace and doing it on her terms. She took an hour and 23 minutes to win her first title at the All England Club since 2012, giving her ownership of all four major championships for the second time in her career.

Williams (33 years, 289 days) becomes the oldest player to win a grand slam singles title in the Open era. She has now won majors in her teens (one), 20s (12) and 30s (eight, a record), and improved to a preposterous 21-4 in finals – redoubling her reputation as the greatest closer in sport.

To be sure the grand slam championships are the recognised metric of greatness and Williams remains one behind Steffi Graf’s 22 for the most won in the Open era.

But Wiliams’ place atop that leaderboard – the last, desperate argument against her undisputed supremacy – seems predestined, given her current form. She has now won 28 consecutive matches at majors – second only to her previous streak of 33 amid her first Serena Slam 12 years ago – and will enter the US Open in seven weeks’ time as the runaway favourite to tick the lone unchecked box on her résumé: a calendar-year grand slam. Victory at Flushing Meadows would move Williams level with Graf, the last player to capture the sport’s four prestige titles in a single season.

Saturday’s latest triumph offered compelling if not overly dramatic theatre. The 21-year-old Muguruza – who had blasted Williams off the court in a Roland Garros stunner last year – was a determined and wildly underestimated opponent who will one day win majors.

Williams, who this week confessed to nerves every time she steps on the court, felt the weight of history and expectations in her opening service game. She double-faulted three times and gave the heavy-hitting Muguruza – one of the few players on tour capable of matching her first-strike pressure – an early dash of confidence.Yet Williams almost immediately began rolling through her service games more quickly and applying pressure on Muguruza’s serve.

From 2-4 down Williams won eight of the next nine games – forcing her Spanish opponent into a high-risk approach beyond her comfort level – and staked a chance to serve for the championship. Yet she tightened late as Centre Court burst into life amid Muguruza’s last-gasp kick, the toe-to-toe exchanges between massive hitters bringing the crowd to their feet, until Muguruza blinked and Williams was the champion again.

In 2011, when Williams confirmed she had suffered a haematoma and pulmonary embolism, there was no guarantee she would ever play tennis at an elite level again, let alone the stratospheric heights she has reached. Since then Williams has accrued a 249-20 match record, an 81-9 mark in majors and eight grand slam titles with an 8-1 record in finals.

She has not simply cleaned out the sport’s heavyweight division: she has scrubbed, cleansed and disinfected it, taking up residence in her rivals’ heads rent-free.

Consider her head-to-head records against the other active players to win major titles: Maria Sharapova (18 wins, two defeats), Svetlana Kuznetsova (8-2), Victoria Azarenka (17-3), Ana Ivanovic (8-1), Petra Kvitova (5-1), Francesca Schiavone (7-2) and Samantha Stosur (8-3). Only the uncomfortable rivalry with her elder sister Venus (15-11), a rivalry fraught with complex emotional depth, is close.

And Williams has done it all as the ultimate outsider, subject to misguided criticism and bigotry throughout her career. She has handled these undue burdens, particularly in the later stages of her illustrious career, with an uncommon strength and grace.

The greatest champions in sport win titles win they are young and keep them till they are old. Now with six titles at SW19, three on the clay of Paris, and six apiece on the hard courts of Melbourne and Flushing Meadows, Wiliams’ greatness is beyond dispute. Whether immortality awaits in New York is almost immaterial.

cards.title: TV / BBC almost certain to retain rights, believes Wimbledon CEO
cards.rawTitle: BBC almost certain to retain rights, believes Wimbledon CEO

item.title: Wimbledon’s chief executive believes BBC almost certain to retain TV rights
item.trailText: Richard Lewis, the man in charge of the All England club, is keen that the current broadcasting arrangement with the BBC continues when the new contract starts in 2017
item.standFirst:
• Richard Lewis complimentary of BBC’s mutually beneficial coverage
• Moving the tournament back a week was a success, says former RFL man
item.body:
Richard Lewis, the chief executive of the All England Lawn Tennis Club, has signalled that the BBC is almost certain to retain the rights to Wimbledon despite the shifting sports rights landscape and budgetary pressures on the broadcaster.

Lewis, who will oversee the tender process for the next contract that runs from 2017, said he saw no reason for the existing relationship to change despite speculation last year suggesting it could become the latest major sporting event to move in part to pay TV.

The speculation had arisen from exploratory talks between the BBC and BT Sport over whether the latter could share some of the rights, perhaps by showing action on the outside courts. But the practicalities would prove difficult, despite the current vogue at the BBC for joint deals as with the FA Cup, Formula One and now the Six Nations – which will be shared with ITV under a new £50m-a-year deal.

Lewis has now confirmed that he is keen to renew Wimbledon’s special 60-year relationship with the BBC. “We have got a very good relationship with the BBC. They do a very good job for us and we do a good job for them. It’s a win-win. I don’t see any reason for it to change,” said Lewis, at the end of a fortnight that has been as popular as ever in ticket sales and ratings.

“They recognise we do a good job for them and are valuable to them. Certainly, we feel that they get us. They are part of us, they understand us. They understand what impact Wimbledon has in the UK, let alone globally. There is a mutual respect and understanding.”

He cites the atmosphere that can build when a big Wimbledon moment is brewing, such as Heather Watson’s match with Serena Williams, with free-to-air blanket coverage on the BBC a key component. “That was a big thing. Someone was telling me they were in a pub in north London and it was like a football match. I can believe it. The centre court atmosphere was very special and it was a great contest.”

Lewis’s comments will reassure the BBC that the club is determined to maintain a relationship that goes back to the beginning of televised sport and will reassure those viewers lamenting the International Olympic Committee’s recent deal with Discovery and the R&A’s with Sky for Open golf. It could also be a gentle reminder to BBC executives considering the impact of reduced licence fee income of the tournament’s importance.

Related: Wimbledon 2Day: BBC admits defeat over format

The BBC is also important to Wimbledon because of its ubiquity during the fortnight and it is an important calling card when selling the brand and TV rights overseas. Lewis even backed the failed experiment of Wimbledon 2Day, the daily programme that quickly morphed back into a version of the traditional highlights amid viewer complaints. “We don’t mind the BBC trying new things. We were fully supportive. It didn’t quite work and they’ve moved back to something that people are enjoying and it’s receiving support,” said Lewis, who succeeded Ian Ritchie in 2012.

The former Rugby Football League and Sport England chairman said moving the tournament back by a week had been an unqualified success and resulted in higher quality matches from the first day because players had enjoyed longer on the grass. “The players have been overwhelmingly positive. With the extra week the players were arriving here earlier and practising more,” he said. “Lots of competition time, lots of practice and good weather. Qualifying week felt a lot busier all round. It has felt like a three-week tournament.”

Lewis must continually maintain a balance between modernising Wimbledon, ensuring it is as accessible as possible to all pockets, while also increasing commercial income and retaining its traditions. On the subject of technology, where smart phones have subtly altered the experience as court side fans keep tabs on other matches, he remained convinced it had successfully walked the line. “It’s something we’ve talked about a lot and the feedback so far is that it’s an improvement and it’s not interfering with people’s enjoyment on the court.

“But that’s always been the thing we want to keep an eye on – if people are sticking tablets in the air or interfering with people’s enjoyment of the match. But we’re not getting any complaints along those lines and the fact people know what is going on around the grounds is adding to people’s enjoyment of the day.”

Around those grounds, there is an air of constant evolution. Phase one of the latest redevelopment plan, digging under courts 14 and 15 to provide more room for catering facilities and storage, is complete. Stage two will be more dramatic, adding a roof, new hospitality areas and 1,000 more seats to No1 Court over the next three years in stages. That redevelopment is being paid for by a new debenture issue that sold out almost immediately, even at double the price of the previous one.

Lewis insisted there was no paradox between the debenture scheme, which allows holders to sell seats at above face value when not in use, and his determination to clamp down on touting. “Ordinary tickets can be sold back to the Club so they can get back their money at face value,” he said. “The debentures is a different type of scheme for funding new facilities. A lot of what is so positive about this place wouldn’t happen if it wasn’t for debentures.”

He said the consumer rights bill would allow the club to be tougher about policing the resale of ordinary tickets for profit, arguing that it is essential to preserve the tournament’s atmosphere. “If you can’t do that and people just buy tickets to sell, that’s a recipe for the organised companies with computer systems and multiple applications,” he said. “I don’t think people would welcome that in the slightest. It is an important part of Wimbledon that tickets are fairly and reasonably priced.”

John McEnroe is among those who have loudly questioned whether the grand slams should take another look at bringing in tie-breaks in the fifth set in light of the demands of the modern game. But Lewis insisted it was part of the unique appeal of the four grand slams. “I understand why it crops up when you see a match like Isner and Cilic going back on court. But I don’t think for that rare, exceptional match that goes on for a long time one should change the whole dynamic,” he said. “It’s part of grand slam tennis. There’s a narrative that builds up that’s unique to grand slam tennis.”

Lewis, who played at Wimbledon 11 times (though progressed beyond the first round only once), ruled out changes to the traditional all white rule in spite of grumbles from some players: “It’s only two weeks of the year, the rest of the year they can wear what they like”.

He also had some words of advice for Nick Kyrgios over the standards required in the famous grounds. “There have to be boundaries. I think that when he learns that people will relax and enjoy his personality and character. There are ballboys and ballgirls, there are spectators, there are TV viewers and people don’t want to watch and hear players go over the line into something that is unseemly.”

Lewis embodies the understated but quietly ambitious modus operandi of the modern Wimbledon – one minute talking enthusiastically about Andy Murray’s form and the next its global brand building ambitions in China and elsewhere. “We’ve got the best of both worlds – some lovely facilities for hospitality and debentures, a royal box that is very special and probably as good as it gets in sport. And then one of the very best public experiences.”

cards.title: Sunday's order of play / Hingis in action again in mixed doubles final
cards.rawTitle: Hingis in action again in mixed doubles final

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: Order of play for Sunday 12 July
item.trailText: Roger Federer and the reigning champion, Novak Djokovic, face each other again in the men’s final, the first match on Centre Court on Sunday
item.standFirst:
• Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer are first on Centre Court in men’s final
• Mixed doubles final follows with Martina Hingis in action
item.body:
CENTRE COURT

2pm start

N DJOKOVIC (Ser, 1) v R FEDERER (Swi, 2); L PAES & M HINGIS (Ind/Swi, 7) v A Peya & T Babos (Aut/Hun, 5)

No1 COURT

1pm

R Opelka (US) v M Ymer (Swe); J Eltingh & P Haarhuis (Neth) v G Forget & C Pioline (Fr); R Opelka & A Santillan (US/Jpn) v Ly Nam Hoang & S Nagal (Vie/Ind)

No3 COURT

11.30am

W Ferreira & S Grosjean (SA/Fr) v G Ivanisevic & I Ljubicic (Cro)

COURT 12

11.30am

D Galfi & F Stollar (Hun) v V Lapko & T Mihalikova (Blr/Svk)

To be arranged

M Navratilova & S Sfar (US/Tun) v M Maleeva & R Stubbs (Bul/Aus)

cards.title: Cyclops / A one-eyed look at Wimbledon

item.title: Cyclops: a one-eyed look at Wimbledon
item.trailText: Featuring Garbiñe Muguruza’s battling, Serena Williams’ age and Scottish vapour trails
item.standFirst: Garbiñe Muguruza’s battling, Serena Williams’ age and Scottish vapour trails
item.body:
BEST ENTRANCE

Related: Serena Williams heads for calendar grand slam beyond Wimbledon records

Plenty expected Garbiñe Muguruza to make an over-respectful, cagey start. She broke in the opening game.

GAME OF THE DAY

Second set, Williams 5-4 Muguruza. Maybe the whole tournament’s best game. The 21-year-old, who had looked done for, produced a stunning battling display to gain an unlikely, match-saving break.

THE PRECEDENT

The omens were never good for the newcomer, though – who was five when Serena Williams won her first major. The last four first-time finalists have all been beaten: Muguruza, Eugenie Bouchard, Sabine Lisicki and Agnieszka Radwanska.

FACT OF THE DAY

At 33 years and 289 days Williams became the oldest player to win a grand slam singles title in the Open era – 26 days more mature than Martina Navratilova when she lifted the Venus Rosewater Dish in 1990.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

Muguruza, explaining her post-match tears: “I couldn’t stop crying. So many people are clapping. I don’t know, I make all these people feel this in a tennis court? I was like, I don’t know. I just felt special.”

AND THE NICEST TOUCH

Williams, consoling Muguruza after collecting her 21st grand slam singles title: “Don’t be sad. You’ll be holding this trophy very soon, believe me. You’re a great champ.”

UNAVOIDABLE CELEB WATCH

Last week was mostly about David Beckham, Romeo Beckham, Romeo’s grandma and David catching a tennis ball. Saturday’s celebs provided some more variety: Canadian rapper Drake, actor Rosamund Pike; and, bringing a touch of class, Lady Mary Crawley from Downton Abbey.

ROW OF THE DAY

How smart was it for the BBC to stick an advert for the Great British Bake Off in the middle of the women’s final? Not very, reckoned Twitter.

BETTER DAY FOR …

After a tough Friday at the hands of Roger Federer, it felt like a better day for Scots at Wimbledon: royalist Nicola Sturgeon graced the royal box, while patriotic vapour trails lingered above Centre Court.

RETURN OF THE DAY

Author JK Rowling, batting away an online troll who tweeted that Serena Williams was “built like a man”. Rowling, who uploaded a picture of the champion in an elegant red dress, said: “Yeah, my husband looks just like this in a dress. You’re an idiot.”

cards.title: Pictures and quotes / The best from the past fortnight at Wimbledon
cards.rawTitle: The best from the past fortnight at Wimbledon

item.title: The best of Wimbledon 2015 — in pictures and quotes
item.trailText: As the climax of the tournament looms, we look back at the most dramatic and stunning photographs by the world’s best sports photographers
item.standFirst: As the climax of the tournament looms, we look back at the most dramatic and stunning photographs by the world’s best sports photographers

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing. Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing.

displayImages.caption: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. The Spaniard was beaten in the second round by Dustin Brown, a German qualifier ranked at No102. After the defeat Nadal said: ‘I just need to accept these kind of things that can happen. I did all my career. Keep going. It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues. My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. The Spaniard was beaten in the second round by Dustin Brown, a German qualifier ranked at No102. After the defeat Nadal said: ‘I just need to accept these kind of things that can happen. I did all my career. Keep going. It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues. My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. The Spaniard was beaten in the second round by Dustin Brown, a German qualifier ranked at No102. After the defeat Nadal said: ‘I just need to accept these kind of things that can happen. I did all my career. Keep going. It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues. My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.’

displayImages.caption: Rafael Nadal shows poise as he serves during his match against Bellucci. After the defeat by Brown, the Spaniard added: ‘My motivation is to try to be back to that level. But if I don’t make that happen, actually I played five times here the last day, had the trophy back home two times, so it is not bad. At the end of the day, I lost. Don’t forget I played five finals here. I don’t know how many players did that.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters

But if I don’t make that happen, actually I played five times here the last day, had the trophy back home two times, so it is not bad. At the end of the day, I lost. Don’t forget I played five finals here. I don’t know how many players did that.’

Don’t forget I played five finals here. I don’t know how many players did that.’

displayImages.caption: Sabine Lisicki returns to Timea Bacsinszky during their third-round match. Lisicki, the 2013 finalist, was beaten in two emphatic sets. Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Sabine Lisicki returns to Timea Bacsinszky during their third-round match. Lisicki, the 2013 finalist, was beaten in two emphatic sets.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sabine Lisicki returns to Timea Bacsinszky during their third-round match. Lisicki, the 2013 finalist, was beaten in two emphatic sets.

displayImages.caption: Nick Kyrgios hugs a ball boy in his match against Richard Gasquet. Kyrgios received a code violation for swearing during play. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air. The Australian appeared uninterested and in a sulk during one game, which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug the ballboy on court. Photograph: Henry Browne/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Nick Kyrgios hugs a ball boy in his match against Richard Gasquet. Kyrgios received a code violation for swearing during play. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air. The Australian appeared uninterested and in a sulk during one game, which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug the ballboy on court.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Nick Kyrgios hugs a ball boy in his match against Richard Gasquet. Kyrgios received a code violation for swearing during play. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air. The Australian appeared uninterested and in a sulk during one game, which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug the ballboy on court.

displayImages.caption: The Australian Fanatics are quiet as they watch Nick Kyrgios lose to Gasquet. ‘You know, I’m not perfect out there. I’m going to have ups and downs,’ Kyrgios said after the defeat. ‘It’s the way you respond from that. I think it takes some serious balls to respond the way I did.’ Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The Australian Fanatics are quiet as they watch Nick Kyrgios lose to Gasquet. ‘You know, I’m not perfect out there. I’m going to have ups and downs,’ Kyrgios said after the defeat. ‘It’s the way you respond from that. I think it takes some serious balls to respond the way I did.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Australian Fanatics are quiet as they watch Nick Kyrgios lose to Gasquet. ‘You know, I’m not perfect out there. I’m going to have ups and downs,’ Kyrgios said after the defeat. ‘It’s the way you respond from that. I think it takes some serious balls to respond the way I did.’

displayImages.caption: Heather Watson applauds the crowd as she leaves the court with Serena Williams. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by the American in a dramatic final set. ‘It was a tough, tough ask but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards. ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’ Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Heather Watson applauds the crowd as she leaves the court with Serena Williams. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by the American in a dramatic final set. ‘It was a tough, tough ask but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards. ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: Heather Watson applauds the crowd as she leaves the court with Serena Williams. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by the American in a dramatic final set. ‘It was a tough, tough ask but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards. ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’

displayImages.caption: Fans on Murray Mound react to the match between Heather Watson and Serena Williams. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She did not think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain, for sure.’ Photograph: Toby Melville/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Fans on Murray Mound react to the match between Heather Watson and Serena Williams. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She did not think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain, for sure.’

An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She did not think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain, for sure.’

displayImages.caption: Vitalia Diatchenko of Russia serves during her match against Anna-Lena Friedsam of Germany as Zarina Diyas of Kazakhstan, foreground, prepares to play a shot as she takes on Flavia Pennetta of Italy. Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Vitalia Diatchenko of Russia serves during her match against Anna-Lena Friedsam of Germany as Zarina Diyas of Kazakhstan, foreground, prepares to play a shot as she takes on Flavia Pennetta of Italy.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Vitalia Diatchenko of Russia serves during her match against Anna-Lena Friedsam of Germany as Zarina Diyas of Kazakhstan, foreground, prepares to play a shot as she takes on Flavia Pennetta of Italy.

displayImages.caption: Roger Federer hits a shot through his legs during his match against Sam Querrey. From a sublime half-volley drop shot to one outrageous rally when, after over-running the ball, he lobbed Querrey with a between-the-legs forehand to win the point, Federer cut his opponent’s big game to pieces with a sublime performance. ‘I’m very happy with the way I’m playing,’ Federer said. ‘I’ve been playing well this season, really since here last year. It’s also a bit of a relief to be playing well at Wimbledon.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Roger Federer hits a shot through his legs during his match against Sam Querrey. From a sublime half-volley drop shot to one outrageous rally when, after over-running the ball, he lobbed Querrey with a between-the-legs forehand to win the point, Federer cut his opponent’s big game to pieces with a sublime performance. ‘I’m very happy with the way I’m playing,’ Federer said. ‘I’ve been playing well this season, really since here last year. It’s also a bit of a relief to be playing well at Wimbledon.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: Roger Federer hits a shot through his legs during his match against Sam Querrey. From a sublime half-volley drop shot to one outrageous rally when, after over-running the ball, he lobbed Querrey with a between-the-legs forehand to win the point, Federer cut his opponent’s big game to pieces with a sublime performance. ‘I’m very happy with the way I’m playing,’ Federer said. ‘I’ve been playing well this season, really since here last year. It’s also a bit of a relief to be playing well at Wimbledon.’

displayImages.caption: Flavia Pennetta reacts after a point against Zarina Diyas during their first-round match on Court 10. Diyas won and was eventually knocked out in the fourth round by Maria Sharapova. Photograph: Justin Tallis/AFP
displayImages.altText: Flavia Pennetta reacts after a point against Zarina Diyas during their first-round match on Court 10. Diyas won and was eventually knocked out in the fourth round by Maria Sharapova.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Flavia Pennetta reacts after a point against Zarina Diyas during their first-round match on Court 10. Diyas won and was eventually knocked out in the fourth round by Maria Sharapova.

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic talks to a small bird on Centre Court during his match against Philipp Kohlschreiber. ‘From where I come from, from the capital of Serbia, Belgrade, there’s a special sparrow bird called jivjum. I believe this bird came all the way from Belgrade to help me,’ Djokovic said after his victory.  Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic talks to a small bird on Centre Court during his match against Philipp Kohlschreiber. ‘From where I come from, from the capital of Serbia, Belgrade, there’s a special sparrow bird called jivjum. I believe this bird came all the way from Belgrade to help me,’ Djokovic said after his victory.

I believe this bird came all the way from Belgrade to help me,’ Djokovic said after his victory.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire. Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire.

displayImages.caption: Dustin Brown returns against Taiwan’s Lu Yen-hsun during their first-round match. Brown sent Rafael Nadal crashing out in the second round. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’ Photograph: Glyn Kirk/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Dustin Brown returns against Taiwan’s Lu Yen-hsun during their first-round match. Brown sent Rafael Nadal crashing out in the second round. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dustin Brown returns against Taiwan’s Lu Yen-hsun during their first-round match. Brown sent Rafael Nadal crashing out in the second round. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’

displayImages.caption: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16. Photograph: Suzanne Plunkett/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16.

displayImages.caption: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. After she beat Maria Sharapova in the semi-finals, she said: ‘It’s never easy to beat such a great player who’s had such a wonderful career. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’ Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. After she beat Maria Sharapova in the semi-finals, she said: ‘It’s never easy to beat such a great player who’s had such a wonderful career. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. After she beat Maria Sharapova in the semi-finals, she said: ‘It’s never easy to beat such a great player who’s had such a wonderful career. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’

displayImages.caption: Vasek Pospisil returns during his win against James Ward. He eventually lost to Andy Murray in the quarter-finals, a match in which he was given two time violations. He vented his frustration. ‘A lot of times these umpires, they seem to just want to be seen. I don’t know why they do it at a time like that. How many times do you see the top guys go more than [30 seconds] and they don’t get any violation, especially when it’s important moments? But I go out there and I get a time violation. I was right about to serve the ball. If he would have waited one second longer, I would have served.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Vasek Pospisil returns during his win against James Ward. He eventually lost to Andy Murray in the quarter-finals, a match in which he was given two time violations. He vented his frustration. ‘A lot of times these umpires, they seem to just want to be seen. I don’t know why they do it at a time like that. How many times do you see the top guys go more than [30 seconds] and they don’t get any violation, especially when it’s important moments? But I go out there and I get a time violation. I was right about to serve the ball. If he would have waited one second longer, I would have served.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: Vasek Pospisil returns during his win against James Ward. He eventually lost to Andy Murray in the quarter-finals, a match in which he was given two time violations. He vented his frustration. ‘A lot of times these umpires, they seem to just want to be seen. I don’t know why they do it at a time like that. How many times do you see the top guys go more than [30 seconds] and they don’t get any violation, especially when it’s important moments? But I go out there and I get a time violation. I was right about to serve the ball. If he would have waited one second longer, I would have served.’

displayImages.caption: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon. Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
displayImages.altText: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon.
displayImages.cleanCaption: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon.

displayImages.caption: Richard Gasquet fires a backhand against Novak Djokovic in their semi-final. Gasquet said afterwards that he had felt under pressure throughout because of the quality of the Djokovic return. ‘He never misses,’ he said. ‘All the time, you serve, you serve. The ball is always on your side again. It’s very difficult. You never make so many aces. He doesn’t make unforced errors. Even from the baseline he’s playing fast with a lot of aggression and takes the ball early. That’s why he’s the world No1.’ Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Richard Gasquet fires a backhand against Novak Djokovic in their semi-final. Gasquet said afterwards that he had felt under pressure throughout because of the quality of the Djokovic return. ‘He never misses,’ he said. ‘All the time, you serve, you serve. The ball is always on your side again. It’s very difficult. You never make so many aces. He doesn’t make unforced errors. Even from the baseline he’s playing fast with a lot of aggression and takes the ball early. That’s why he’s the world No1.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: Richard Gasquet fires a backhand against Novak Djokovic in their semi-final. Gasquet said afterwards that he had felt under pressure throughout because of the quality of the Djokovic return. ‘He never misses,’ he said. ‘All the time, you serve, you serve. The ball is always on your side again. It’s very difficult. You never make so many aces. He doesn’t make unforced errors. Even from the baseline he’s playing fast with a lot of aggression and takes the ball early. That’s why he’s the world No1.’
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Slovenia’s Polona Hercog serves against US player Lauren Davis during their first-round match. Photograph: Leon Neal/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Slovenia’s Polona Hercog serves against US player Lauren Davis during their first round match.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Slovenia’s Polona Hercog serves against US player Lauren Davis during their first-round match.

displayImages.caption: Andy Murray talks to Roger Federer after losing to the Swiss player in the semi-finals. ‘At times I played some very good tennis and I served well – the best I had served in the tournament myself,’ said a downbeat Murray after the match. ‘All losses hurt, especially in the major events.’ Photograph: Toby Melville/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Andy Murray talks to Roger Federer after losing to the Swiss player in the semi-finals. ‘At times I played some very good tennis and I served well – the best I had served in the tournament myself,’ said a downbeat Murray after the match. ‘All losses hurt, especially in the major events.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: Andy Murray talks to Roger Federer after losing to the Swiss player in the semi-finals. ‘At times I played some very good tennis and I served well – the best I had served in the tournament myself,’ said a downbeat Murray after the match. ‘All losses hurt, especially in the major events.’

image.caption: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing. Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
image.altText: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing.
image.cleanCaption: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing.

image.caption: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. The Spaniard was beaten in the second round by Dustin Brown, a German qualifier ranked at No102. After the defeat Nadal said: ‘I just need to accept these kind of things that can happen. I did all my career. Keep going. It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues. My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
image.altText: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. The Spaniard was beaten in the second round by Dustin Brown, a German qualifier ranked at No102. After the defeat Nadal said: ‘I just need to accept these kind of things that can happen. I did all my career. Keep going. It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues. My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.’
image.cleanCaption: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. The Spaniard was beaten in the second round by Dustin Brown, a German qualifier ranked at No102. After the defeat Nadal said: ‘I just need to accept these kind of things that can happen. I did all my career. Keep going. It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues. My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.’

image.caption: Rafael Nadal shows poise as he serves during his match against Bellucci. After the defeat by Brown, the Spaniard added: ‘My motivation is to try to be back to that level. But if I don’t make that happen, actually I played five times here the last day, had the trophy back home two times, so it is not bad. At the end of the day, I lost. Don’t forget I played five finals here. I don’t know how many players did that.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters

I believe this bird came all the way from Belgrade to help me,’ Djokovic said after his victory.  Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
image.altText: Novak Djokovic talks to a small bird on Centre Court during his match against Philipp Kohlschreiber. ‘From where I come from, from the capital of Serbia, Belgrade, there’s a special sparrow bird called jivjum. I believe this bird came all the way from Belgrade to help me,’ Djokovic said after his victory.

image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

image.caption: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire. Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
image.altText: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire.
image.cleanCaption: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire.

image.caption: Dustin Brown returns against Taiwan’s Lu Yen-hsun during their first-round match. Brown sent Rafael Nadal crashing out in the second round. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’ Photograph: Glyn Kirk/AFP/Getty Images
image.altText: Dustin Brown returns against Taiwan’s Lu Yen-hsun during their first-round match. Brown sent Rafael Nadal crashing out in the second round. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’

image.caption: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16. Photograph: Suzanne Plunkett/Reuters
image.altText: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16.
image.cleanCaption: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16.

image.caption: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. After she beat Maria Sharapova in the semi-finals, she said: ‘It’s never easy to beat such a great player who’s had such a wonderful career. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’ Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
image.altText: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. After she beat Maria Sharapova in the semi-finals, she said: ‘It’s never easy to beat such a great player who’s had such a wonderful career. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’
image.cleanCaption: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. After she beat Maria Sharapova in the semi-finals, she said: ‘It’s never easy to beat such a great player who’s had such a wonderful career. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’

image.caption: Vasek Pospisil returns during his win against James Ward. He eventually lost to Andy Murray in the quarter-finals, a match in which he was given two time violations. He vented his frustration. ‘A lot of times these umpires, they seem to just want to be seen. I don’t know why they do it at a time like that. How many times do you see the top guys go more than [30 seconds] and they don’t get any violation, especially when it’s important moments? But I go out there and I get a time violation. I was right about to serve the ball. If he would have waited one second longer, I would have served.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
image.altText: Vasek Pospisil returns during his win against James Ward. He eventually lost to Andy Murray in the quarter-finals, a match in which he was given two time violations. He vented his frustration. ‘A lot of times these umpires, they seem to just want to be seen. I don’t know why they do it at a time like that. How many times do you see the top guys go more than [30 seconds] and they don’t get any violation, especially when it’s important moments? But I go out there and I get a time violation. I was right about to serve the ball. If he would have waited one second longer, I would have served.’

He vented his frustration. ‘A lot of times these umpires, they seem to just want to be seen. I don’t know why they do it at a time like that. How many times do you see the top guys go more than [30 seconds] and they don’t get any violation, especially when it’s important moments? But I go out there and I get a time violation. I was right about to serve the ball. If he would have waited one second longer, I would have served.’

image.caption: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon. Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
image.altText: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon.
image.cleanCaption: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon.

image.caption: Richard Gasquet fires a backhand against Novak Djokovic in their semi-final. Gasquet said afterwards that he had felt under pressure throughout because of the quality of the Djokovic return. ‘He never misses,’ he said. ‘All the time, you serve, you serve. The ball is always on your side again. It’s very difficult. You never make so many aces. He doesn’t make unforced errors. Even from the baseline he’s playing fast with a lot of aggression and takes the ball early. That’s why he’s the world No1.’ Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
image.altText: Richard Gasquet fires a backhand against Novak Djokovic in their semi-final. Gasquet said afterwards that he had felt under pressure throughout because of the quality of the Djokovic return. ‘He never misses,’ he said. ‘All the time, you serve, you serve. The ball is always on your side again. It’s very difficult. You never make so many aces. He doesn’t make unforced errors. Even from the baseline he’s playing fast with a lot of aggression and takes the ball early. That’s why he’s the world No1.’

Gasquet said afterwards that he had felt under pressure throughout because of the quality of the Djokovic return. ‘He never misses,’ he said. ‘All the time, you serve, you serve. image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

image.caption: Slovenia’s Polona Hercog serves against US player Lauren Davis during their first-round match. Photograph: Leon Neal/AFP/Getty Images
image.altText: Slovenia’s Polona Hercog serves against US player Lauren Davis during their first round match.
image.cleanCaption: Slovenia’s Polona Hercog serves against US player Lauren Davis during their first-round match.

image.caption: Andy Murray talks to Roger Federer after losing to the Swiss player in the semi-finals. ‘At times I played some very good tennis and I served well – the best I had served in the tournament myself,’ said a downbeat Murray after the match. ‘All losses hurt, especially in the major events.’ Photograph: Toby Melville/Reuters
image.altText: Andy Murray talks to Roger Federer after losing to the Swiss player in the semi-finals. ‘At times I played some very good tennis and I served well – the best I had served in the tournament myself,’ said a downbeat Murray after the match. ‘All losses hurt, especially in the major events.’

cards.title: Girls' doubles / Brogan and Christie lose in semi-final
cards.rawTitle: Brogan and Christie lose in semi-final

item.title: Anna Brogan and Freya Christie lose in Wimbledon girls’ doubles semi
item.trailText: British interest in the girls’ doubles at Wimbledon ended when Anna Brogan and Freya Christie were beaten 6-4, 7-5 by Vera Lapko and Tereza Mihalikova in a high-quality semi-final
item.standFirst:
• Vera Lapko and Tereza Mihalikova win 6-4, 7-5
• British pair beaten after taking 4-1 lead in opening set
item.body:
Britain’s wait for home champions in the girls’ doubles goes on for at least another year after Anna Brogan of Scotland and England’s Freya Christie were narrowly beaten in a high-quality semi-final on Saturday. The 17-year-old pair led 4-1 in the first set and recovered from 4-1 down in the second but were eventually beaten 6-4, 7-5 by Vera Lapko of Belarus and Tereza Mihalikova of Slovakia, who have a chance to win their first grand slam title together, having missed out in the final at the US Open last summer.

Elizabeth Jelfs is the only Briton to win the title here, in 1994, but Brogan and Christie began well, racing to a 3-0 and 4-1 lead only to be hauled back. In the second set the pair recovered well and at 5-5 they had momentum but Mihalikova, who won the singles at this year’s Australian Open, and Lapko stepped up another gear to clinch victory.

Related: Jamie Murray misses out on second Wimbledon doubles crown

“It’s gutting, to be honest,” Christie said. “When we look back we’ll think we had a good week and played some good tennis but right now I don’t think we’re too happy.”

Brogan made a small dent in Court No1 when she threw her racket in frustration at one stage. “It’s funny, in the coin toss the umpire says: ‘Please look after the court, it’s very important,’” she said. “I don’t throw my racket normally. To do that at Wimbledon’s probably not ideal. I’m not sure what my granny would have thought watching that.”

The Scot said she had barely slept the night before, so excited had she been at the prospect of playing for a place in the final. “I was absolutely buzzing, my adrenaline was going,” she said. “I was up from two in the morning till about four just thinking.”

The pair, who said they hoped to make it into the main draw next year, signed numerous autographs as they left the court. “That’s stuff you take to your grave, as cliched as it sounds,” Brogan said. “I’m going to remember that for the rest of my life. I had goosebumps walking out there.”

displayImages.caption: Freya Christie, left and Anna Brogan during their semi-final of the girls' doubles at Wimbledon. Photograph: Jonathan Brady/PA
